data.title: Ecovyst outlines $860M–$940M 2026 sales target as company strengthens balance sheet and pursues growth through mining and capital allocation
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Ecovyst Inc. (ECVT) Q4 2025

Management View

  • CEO Kurt Bitting stated the company was “very pleased with our fourth quarter results and the execution of our strategic objectives.” He emphasized that “strong sales volume for virgin sulfuric acid and favorable contractual pricing for regeneration services contributed to a solid quarter,” leading to full year 2025 adjusted EBITDA above guidance despite unplanned and extended customer downtime.
  • Bitting announced the completion of the divestiture of the Advanced Materials and Catalysts segment earlier than expected for $556 million, with $465 million of net proceeds used to pay down the term loan, resulting in a net debt leverage ratio of 1.2x at year end. He described this as having “transformed the company, initiating a new focus to drive progress by delivering reliable sulfur solutions for clean fuels and critical materials.”
  • The company acquired the Waggaman sulfuric acid assets for approximately $40 million and repurchased just under $50 million of common stock in 2025. Bitting said, “We enter 2026 with a strong balance sheet and significant liquidity that we believe positions us well to continue our capital allocation priorities directed at growth, both organic and inorganic, and the continued return of capital to our stockholders.”
  • CFO Michael Feehan highlighted, “We closed out the year with a solid financial performance in the fourth quarter, delivering full year adjusted EBITDA of $172 million ahead of our previously provided guidance.” He reported $78 million of free cash flow and noted, “With the proceeds from the sale of the AM&C business, we paid down $465 million of our term loan, resulting in a 1.2x net leverage ratio, leaving $265 million of available liquidity.”

Outlook

  • Management expects 2026 to include “higher sales volume for both virgin sulfuric acid, driven by higher projected mining demand, and higher volume for regeneration sulfuric acid as we expect less customer downtime compared to 2025.”
  • Feehan projected full year 2026 sales to be in the range of $860 million to $940 million, with full year adjusted EBITDA expected to fall in the range of $175 million to $195 million.
  • The company anticipates higher turnaround costs by approximately $8 million in 2026 and expects capital expenditures will be $20 million higher, resulting in a range of $80 million to $90 million.
  • Adjusted free cash flow is expected to be in the range of $35 million to $55 million, and interest expense is anticipated to be $18 million to $22 million in 2026.

Financial Results

  • Fourth quarter sales were $199 million, up $51 million or 34%. Excluding a $28 million impact of higher sulfur costs passed through in price, sales were up 15%.
  • Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter was $51 million, up 8% from the prior year. Feehan attributed this to a “favorable volume and price impact at a sales level, partially offset by higher planned fixed manufacturing costs, including incremental costs of the acquired Waggaman assets.”
  • The adjusted EBITDA margin decreased by 630 basis points compared to the fourth quarter of 2024, mainly due to the pass-through effect of higher sulfur costs accounting for approximately 500 basis points of the decrease.
  • Free cash flow for the year was $78 million, supporting share repurchases totaling $47 million for 2025.

Q&A

  • John McNulty, BMO Capital Markets: Asked about Waggaman asset capacity and future growth. Bitting responded, “The Waggaman sulfuric acid assets that we added last year, of course, added roughly around 10% of volume to the overall network... it’s a force multiplier really with our Gulf Coast network.”
  • McNulty, BMO Capital Markets: Inquired about regeneration contract pricing lift for 2026. Feehan replied, “It’s going to be a similar lift... every year, the contractual agreements that we have start to roll off. It’s usually between 15% and 20% a year... it does provide a benefit.”
  • Patrick Cunningham, Citigroup: Sought specifics on industrial application weakness. Bitting explained, “It’s just a general sense of caution in that space. For us, our biggest one is... nylon... we expect to be roughly on par with where we were in 2025.”
  • Aleksey Yefremov, KeyBanc: Asked if expansion is tied to customer contracts or anticipated growth. Bitting said, “We’re confident that the demand will be there. And we feel it’s appropriate for us to add this additional capacity and logistics capacity to meet that growing demand long-term.”
  • David Begleiter, Deutsche Bank: Asked about guidance range drivers. Bitting noted, “Upper end it’s going to be the virgin acid and if there’s some positivity in things like pricing or spot volumes... on the low end... that largely would be driven by things like unplanned customer outages... or a macroeconomic event.”

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed for clarity on capacity growth, contract repricing, market conditions, and capital allocation, with a neutral to slightly positive tone, showing interest in strategic direction but expressing caution on industrial demand.
  • Management maintained a confident and proactive tone, emphasizing resilience, balance sheet strength, and flexibility. Feehan stated, “We believe that we have significant flexibility as we look to fund our growth initiatives.”
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone shifted from cautious optimism to increased confidence, supported by the completed divestiture and strengthened balance sheet. Analysts’ tone remained steady, with consistent focus on execution and demand trends.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance language shifted from high-level commentary last quarter to explicit ranges for sales and adjusted EBITDA for 2026.
  • Strategic focus moved from anticipated portfolio transformation to execution, with the divestiture completed and proceeds deployed.
  • Analysts continued to focus on capital allocation, demand drivers, and customer contract stability, now probing for more granular guidance and growth metrics.
  • Key metrics such as net debt leverage improved from below 1.5x to 1.2x, and free cash flow met or exceeded prior ranges.
  • Management’s confidence increased, highlighting the company’s ability to pursue both organic and inorganic growth, while analysts maintained a measured approach, probing for risks and upside scenarios.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management remained cautious about “the near-term outlook for the nylon applications and some of the industrial applications,” with expectations for nylon-related sales to be flat year-over-year.
  • Macro factors and unplanned customer outages were noted as potential risks that could “translate into softer demand in some areas.”
  • Feehan highlighted that sulfur costs are expected to be “up significantly this year,” but noted these are passed through with no material impact on adjusted EBITDA.
  • Analysts questioned whether investments at Waggaman were complete, to which Bitting replied there were “additional investments necessary in the near future.”

Final Takeaway

Ecovyst’s management emphasized the company’s successful transformation following the divestiture of the Advanced Materials and Catalysts segment, with a strengthened balance sheet, explicit 2026 guidance, and targeted investments in mining-related growth and logistics. Management expects higher volumes and stable pricing in key segments, while maintaining a disciplined approach to capital allocation and shareholder returns. Risks remain in select industrial end markets and from potential customer outages, but the company’s liquidity and network enhancements position it to pursue further growth and value creation for shareholders in 2026 and beyond.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Zscaler targets $3.745B ARR for 2026 as AI security and Zero Trust adoption accelerate
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Zscaler (ZS) Q2 2026

Management View

  • CEO Jagtar Chaudhry reported "ARR grew 25%, reflecting continued strong demand for our platform" and highlighted increased guidance across the board. Chaudhry positioned Zscaler as "the security platform for the AI era," stating, "We believe we are uniquely positioned to secure the AI transformation, driving continued demand for our platform."
  • Chaudhry described rapid AI adoption as creating "new vulnerabilities, significantly expanding the attack surface and increasing cyber threats in scale, sophistication and speed" and cited conversations with over 100 CEOs and CIOs about the urgency of AI security.
  • Product momentum was attributed to three growth pillars: "AI Security, Zero Trust Everywhere, and Data Security Everywhere." AI Protect, a recently introduced solution, is seeing "demand rapidly accelerating, including landing new logos, representing a massive future growth opportunity." Notable wins included an 8-figure deal with a Fortune 500 semiconductor manufacturer and a 7-figure upsell with a Global 2000 construction company.
  • The Zero Trust Everywhere customer base grew to "over 550, up from over 130 a year ago," with notable deployment expansions in both Branch and Cloud solutions. Data Security Everywhere saw an 8-figure upsell from a Global 2000 financial services customer.
  • CFO Kevin Rubin stated, "We delivered strong Q2 '26 results, exceeding our targets while investing with discipline. With 26% revenue growth and a 36% free cash flow margin, we achieved Rule of 62 performance in the first half of the year."
  • Rubin highlighted that "non-seat-based metered usage solutions delivered just over 1/4 of new ACV and the ARR tied to those offerings grew more than 100% year-over-year."
  • Z-Flex, a customer flexibility program, generated more than $290 million in TCV, up over 65% quarter-over-quarter, with $650 million in TCV since launch.

Outlook

  • Rubin provided guidance for Q3: "revenue of $834 million to $836 million," "gross margin of approximately 80%", and "earnings per share of $1 to $1.01."
  • For full year fiscal 2026, Rubin projected "ARR of $3.730 billion to $3.745 billion or year-over-year growth of approximately 24%", "revenue of $3.309 billion to $3.322 billion," "operating profit of $742 million to $748 million," and "earnings per share of $3.99 to $4.02."
  • Red Canary is expected to deliver "ARR of approximately $130 million in fiscal '26, up from our prior guidance of $95 million."

Financial Results

  • Zscaler reported "revenue of $816 million grew 26% year-over-year and 4% sequentially, exceeding the high end of our guidance."
  • Net new ARR was $156 million, up 19%. Total ARR reached $3.4 billion, up 25% year-over-year.
  • Zscaler closed Q2 with 728 customers generating over $1 million of ARR and 3,886 customers exceeding $100,000 in ARR, both growing 18% year-over-year.
  • Remaining performance obligation (RPO) stood at $6.1 billion, up approximately 31%.
  • Non-GAAP gross margin was 80.2%. Non-GAAP operating income was $181 million, and free cash flow margin was 20.7%.

Q&A

  • Saket Kalia, Barclays: Asked about competitive dynamics and win rates. Chaudhry responded, "We haven't seen much change in the competitive dynamics over the past few quarters," and emphasized record pipeline conversion and large deal wins.
  • Brad Zelnick, Deutsche Bank: Sought clarity on ARR expectations and seasonality. Rubin replied, "Our business seasonality tends to favor H2. So we are going into the second half of the year feeling confident."
  • Gregg Moskowitz, Mizuho: Inquired about non-seat-based solutions. Chaudhry highlighted growth, stating "1/4 of our new business came from metered usage, and we expect it to grow over time, especially with AI agents."
  • Brian Essex, JPMorgan: Asked if Zscaler is benefiting from budgets outside of security. Chaudhry noted, "We're not seeing budgets as an issue to do AI security projects."
  • Meta Marshall, Morgan Stanley: Asked about sales cycle dynamics for AI deals. Chaudhry described sales cycles as "generally faster" and driven by demand for integrated solutions.
  • Fatima Boolani, Citi: Asked about Red Canary churn and ARR revision. Rubin explained, "As we do secure the renewals, there is a positive impact to ARR."
  • Roger Boyd, UBS: Questioned future sales productivity. Chaudhry and Rubin both projected continued improvement.
  • Ittai Kidron, Oppenheimer: Sought color on core ZIA, ZPA growth. Rubin said performance was "pretty consistent" and highlighted large remaining market opportunity.
  • Gray Powell, BTIG: Asked about Z-Flex's ARR impact. Rubin clarified, "Z-Flex is by their nature, because they're longer term, they've got more products, they may have a ramp that is built in."
  • Jonathan Ruykhaver, Cantor Fitzgerald: Asked about SquareX and browser security. Chaudhry emphasized the flexibility of extension-based security.
  • Eric Heath, KeyBanc: Asked about monetizing AI agent traffic. Chaudhry responded, "The more agents, the more agentic traffic, the more value we deliver, and the better revenue opportunity for us."
  • Matthew Hedberg, RBC: Asked for clarity on ARR raise. Rubin explained, "We are raising the organic net new from 6.7% as our initial raise in the beginning of the year to 9.5% growth for '26."
  • Keith Bachman, BMO: Inquired about Zero Trust Everywhere. Chaudhry stated, "We are seeing 2x to 3x essentially move in the ARR when customers are moving to Zero Trust Everywhere."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts' tone was largely positive, focusing on product growth, sales models, and clarity around new business lines and acquisitions, though several probed for details on Red Canary churn and ARR contributions.
  • Management's sentiment in prepared remarks was confident, with frequent references to "strong demand," "record pipeline conversion," and "durable runway for long-term growth." During Q&A, management maintained a positive and informative approach, offering direct answers and reiterating key messages.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analyst sentiment shifted from curiosity about product and deal pipeline to more pointed questions on new solutions, financial contributions, and integration impacts. Management's tone remained highly confident but addressed more detailed inquiries about the evolving business model and acquisitions.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for ARR, revenue, and operating profit was raised compared to Q1, with higher expectations for both core and acquired businesses. The full-year ARR range increased from $3.698 billion to $3.745 billion.
  • Strategic focus sharpened further on AI Security, with the launch and integration of new modules and expanded customer examples. Zero Trust Everywhere customer penetration grew strongly, from over 450 to over 550 enterprises in one quarter.
  • Analysts shifted from exploring Z-Flex's initial adoption and Red Canary integration to deeper questions about financial contribution, churn, and sales model dynamics.
  • Management's confidence remained high, but there was increased emphasis on product differentiation, integration, and the value of larger, more strategic deals.

Risks and Concerns

  • Rubin addressed hardware supply challenges, stating, "recent increases in memory, storage and processor prices and availability...could become a factor in the future as we purchase equipment for our data centers and Zero Trust Branch appliances."
  • Elevated churn in the Red Canary business post-acquisition was noted, though management described ongoing integration and positive ARR impact from renewals.
  • No meaningful impact from hardware cost increases yet, but management is monitoring the situation and may adjust pricing if needed.

Final Takeaway

Zscaler delivered robust Q2 results, raising guidance for revenue, ARR, and operating profit on the strength of demand for its AI Security and Zero Trust solutions. The company saw rapid expansion in non-seat-based solutions, significant momentum in large and strategic deals, and increased customer adoption of integrated offerings. Management expressed confidence in continued growth, citing a large addressable market, durable demand drivers, and successful execution of both organic and acquired growth strategies.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: European markets broadly muted, weighed by tech worries
Meta inks yet another AI chip deal, this time with Google - report
data.description:
Meta Platforms (META) inked a multi-billion-dollar deal to rent artificial intelligence chips from Google (GOOGL), The Information reported, citing a person involved in the talks.

Meta (META) is also in talks to buy Google's (GOOGL) Tensor Processing Units (TPUs) for its data centers as early as 2027. It's unclear how advanced these discussions are.

The report added that Google (GOOGL) and an unidentified large investment firm reached a deal for funding a joint venture that would lease TPUs to other customers.

Google's (GOOGL) TPUs are custom-developed chips designed for training and inference of AI models cost-efficiently. It is reportedly pushing to make its TPUs a viable alternative to Nvidia's market-leading GPUs.

Tech companies have been ramping up investments in AI chips and infrastructure to maintain their edge in the AI race.

Meta (META) this week said it would deploy up to 6 gigawatts of AMD (AMD) chips to power its next generation of AI infrastructure. Last week, Meta struck a deal to use millions of Nvidia (NVDA) chips in its AI data centers.

data.title: Prediction market odds rise for Pentagon banning Anthropic AI model
data.description:
Prediction market traders repriced the odds that Pete Hegseth will ban Anthropic’s (ANTHRO) Claude AI model by March 31, with probabilities spiking earlier this week before pulling back.

On Feb. 25, Polymarket (POLYMARKET) showed a 49% chance of a ban, marking a sharp jump from the low-to-mid teens seen in prior days. The move represented a roughly 35% surge in implied probability in a short span, suggesting traders were reacting to new developments around Anthropic’s standoff with the Pentagon.

 

 

The AI startup has been engaged in tense negotiations with the Pentagon lately, and it said Thursday that those discussions are still ongoing. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has threatened to label Anthropic a “supply chain risk” or to invoke the Defense Production Act to force the company to comply with its demands.

Anthropic (ANTHRO) on Thursday said that the company “cannot in good conscience” allow the Department of Defense to use its models in all lawful use cases without limitation, adding that the agency’s threats do not change its position.

The company had signed a $200M contract with the Pentagon in July, becoming the first lab to deploy its models in mission workflows on classified networks. Rivals OpenAI (OPENAI), Google (GOOG), and xAI (X.AI) also received DoD awards worth up to $200M last year.

By early Feb. 27, the odds of the Pentagon taking action against Anthropic had eased to 42% on Polymarket, though still well above levels seen before the spike. The volatility indicates traders are split on whether regulatory action will materialize within the tight timeline.

 

 

On Kalshi (KALSHI), traders are similarly pricing higher odds of Pentagon action, with about a 43% chance of the AI company being designated a supply chain risk on Feb. 27.

data.title: Mesoblast misses H1 estimates
data.description:
• Mesoblast press release (MESO): 1H GAAP EPS of -$3.11 misses by $3.06.
  • Revenue of $51.3M (+1503.1% Y/Y) misses by $4.48M.
  • Ryoncil® gross profit, excluding amortization, was US$44.2 million versus nil in the prior year period. Direct selling costs were US$7.7 million.

data.title: Vallourec S.A. reports Q4 results
data.description:
• Vallourec S.A. press release (VLOUF): Q4
  • Revenue of €1.04B(-2.1% Y/Y)
  • Q4 Group EBITDA of €214 million, strong 21% EBITDA margin
  • Excellent total cash generation of €177 million
  • Around €650 million distribution to shareholders targeted by August 2026
  • Q1 2026 Group EBITDA expected to range between €165 million and €195 million

  • OUTLOOK

    First Quarter 2026 Group EBITDA is expected to range between €165 million and €195 million:

    • In Tubes, EBITDA per tonne is expected to be broadly in-line with the Q4 2025 level, while volumes are expected to be below the Q4 2025 level.

data.title: Earnings Snapshot: Duolingo DAU growth slows, EBITDA margins dip before rebounding in Q4, and revenue to rise 15–18% in 2026
Compañía de Minas Buenaventura beats Q4 estimates
data.description:
• Compañía de Minas Buenaventura press release (BVN): Q4 GAAP EPS of $1.51 beats by $0.75.
  • Revenue of $623.4M (+108.1% Y/Y) beats by $171.8M.
  • Buenaventura's 4Q25 consolidated silver production increased by 2% YoY driven by increased production at Tambomayo. Lead production increased by 58% YoY.
  • 4Q25 EBITDA from direct operations was US$ 353.5 million, compared to US$ 93.4 million reported in 4Q24.
  • 4Q25 net income reached US$ 383.6 million, compared to US$ 33.6 million in the same period of 2024.
